question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The company r̲a̲n̲ ̲a̲b̲o̲u̲t̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲s̲t̲o̲c̲k̲ ̲d̲u̲e̲ ̲t̲o̲ unexpectedly high demand for the product.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.53_05-Nov_Shift-3)
option_1: ran across of stock due to
option_2: ran on of stock due to
option_3: ran out of stock due to
option_4: ran around of stock due to
solution:
Answer: c) ran out of stock due to

Explanation:
The correct phrase is "ran out of stock", which means to use up all the available stock (स्टॉक खत्म हो जाना).

  • Ran out of stock due to correctly explains that the stock was exhausted because of high demand.

  • Other options like ran across of, ran on of, and ran around of are incorrect and do not form meaningful phrases in this context.

So, the correct substitution is "ran out of stock due to".

question:
Select the option that corrects the Phrasal Verb (appearing in bold letters) in the given sentence.
The burglars b̲r̲o̲k̲e̲ ̲o̲f̲f̲ my neighbour's house when they were away.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.57_12-Nov_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: broke into

Explanation:
The correct phrasal verb for illegally entering a building is "broke into" (घर में जबरन घुस जाना).

  • Broke off means to end something abruptly (रोक देना)

  • Broke down means to stop working or collapse (खराब हो जाना)

  • Broke away means to escape or leave (भाग जाना)

So, the correct phrase is:
"The burglars broke into my neighbour's house when they were away."

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Shirin c̲a̲m̲e̲ ̲o̲f̲f̲ ̲w̲i̲t̲h̲ ̲a̲ ̲b̲r̲i̲l̲l̲i̲a̲n̲t̲ ̲i̲d̲e̲a̲ to solve the problem.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.59_12-Nov_Shift-3)
option_1: came off on a brilliant idea
option_2: came up in a brilliant idea
option_3: came off to a brilliant idea
option_4: came up with a brilliant idea
solution:
Answer: came up with a brilliant idea

Explanation:
The correct phrase is "came up with" when talking about thinking of or producing an idea (कोई विचार निकालना).

  • Other options are incorrect or meaningless in this context:

  • came off on

  • came up in

  • came off to

So, the correct substitution is "came up with a brilliant idea."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
If we want to promote national integrity in our country, then we must desist our tendency of t̲a̲k̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲u̲p̲ ̲w̲i̲t̲h̲ others.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.63_14-Nov_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: looking down upon

Explanation:
The phrase "taking up with others" in this context is about negative behavior towards others.

  • Looking down upon means to regard others as inferior or disrespect them (तलमटोल करना या नीचा समझना), which fits here as something to desist from.

  • Bringing forward, coming round, and setting out do not convey this meaning.

So, "looking down upon" is the correct substitute.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The most effective way to enhance your vocabulary is to l̲o̲o̲k̲ ̲t̲o̲ unknown words in a dictionary.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.8_07-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct answer:look up

Explanation:

The phrasal verb "look up" means to search for information (such as the meaning of a word) in a reference book or database, which fits perfectly in this context.

  • Stand against – means to oppose → incorrect

  • Look up – means to search for information → correct

  • Set by – means to regard or consider → incorrect

  • Write off – means to dismiss or ignore → incorrect

Correct sentence:
"The most effective way to enhance your vocabulary is to look up unknown words in a dictionary."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Once the seminar was over, the host g̲a̲v̲e̲ ̲u̲p̲ the certificates to the active participants.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.8_07-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct answer: gave away

Explanation:

  • The phrasal verb "gave away" means to distribute or hand out something, which fits the context of distributing certificates.

  • Other options:

  • brought about – means caused something to happen, incorrect here.

  • came by – means to visit or obtain something, incorrect here.

  • put across – means to communicate or explain, incorrect here.

Correct sentence:
"Once the seminar was over, the host gave away the certificates to the active participants."

question:
Select the most appropriate phrasal verb that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The firefighters tried their best to e̲x̲t̲i̲n̲g̲u̲i̲s̲h̲ the fire.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-2)
solution:
Explanation:

Put out means to extinguish or stop something from burning, which is exactly what firefighters do with a fire.

The other options are:

  • Put on means to place something on the surface of something else.

  • Put in means to insert something into a space.

  • Put off means to delay or postpone something.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required.’
I decided to c̲a̲l̲l̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲ to various bookstores in the area to see if any of them had the book I needed.

(SSC CHSL 2023 T-2 (2 Nov))
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is:

"I decided to call around to various bookstores in the area to see if any of them had the book I needed."

Call off:This phrase means to cancel something. For example, "call off the search" means to cancel or stop searching.

Call around: This phrase means to contact or inquire widely, often to different places or people. In the context of the sentence, the speaker is checking with various bookstores to find the needed book.

Call on:This phrase often means to visit someone, especially for a brief period. It doesn't fit the context of checking with bookstores in different locations.

he sentence intends to convey the idea of checking with various bookstores, and the phrase "call around" is a colloquial and appropriate way to express this action.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He was l̲o̲o̲k̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲i̲n̲t̲o̲ ̲h̲i̲s̲ ̲b̲o̲o̲k̲ for the last two hours but couldn’t find it.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 1 Dec Shift-1)
option_3: looking down on his book
solution:
Correct Answer: looking for his book

Explanation:
The phrase "looking into his book" means examining or reading carefully (ध्यान से जाँच करना), which doesn't suit this sentence. The person is clearly trying to find his book, so "looking for his book," meaning searching (ढूँढ़ना), fits correctly.

Other options are incorrect because:

  • "looking above his book" means looking over or higher than the book (किताब के ऊपर देखना), not searching.

  • "looking after his book" means taking care of (देखभाल करना), which doesn't fit here.

  • "looking down on his book" suggests disrespecting or considering inferior (नीचा समझना या अपमान करना), which also isn't appropriate here.

Thus, the correct sentence is:
"He was looking for his book for the last two hours but couldn’t find it."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The story did not g̲o̲ ̲b̲y̲ well enough.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: 2 (go down)

Solution:
The sentence is:
"The story did not go by well enough."

The phrase “go by” is incorrect in this context. To describe how something was received, accepted, or perceived, the correct phrasal verb is “go down”.

✔ “Go down well” means to be received positively or to be accepted or liked by people.

So, the correct sentence is:
"The story did not go down well enough."

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Go off – usually refers to an explosion or an event happening, not fitting here.

  • Go through – means to experience or examine something, not about being received well.

  • Go into – means to discuss or enter into something, unrelated to reception.

Phrasal Verb Meaning:

  • Go down (well) – to be well-received or appreciated (किसी को पसंद आना)

  • Go off – to explode or start suddenly (फट जाना/शुरू होना)

  • Go through – to experience or undergo (गुजरना)

  • Go into – to explore in detail (विवरण में जाना)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He is a weak student and somehow p̲u̲l̲l̲e̲d̲ ̲o̲v̲e̲r̲ the exams.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: 1 (pulled through)

Solution:
The original sentence is:
"He is a weak student and somehow pulled over the exams."

The phrase “pulled over” is incorrect here. It usually refers to stopping a vehicle at the side of the road.

The correct idiom is “pulled through”, which means to succeed in dealing with a difficult situation, especially to survive or succeed against the odds — which fits perfectly for a weak student barely managing to pass exams.

✔ Correct sentence:
"He is a weak student and somehow pulled through the exams."

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Pulled up – means to stop or to reprimand someone (झिड़कना)

  • Pulled together – means to unite or cooperate (एकजुट होना)

  • Pulled down – means to demolish or reduce (गिरा देना)

Phrasal Verb Meaning:

  • Pull through – to survive or succeed in a tough situation (मुश्किल में भी पार पा लेना)

✅ Therefore, “pulled through” is the most appropriate substitute.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
 How did you c̲o̲m̲e̲ ̲a̲b̲o̲u̲t̲ his purse?

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 4 – come by

Solution (Correct Option – 4: come by):
The phrasal verb “come by” means to obtain or acquire something, often by chance or effort (कुछ पाना या हासिल करना)।
So the sentence:
"How did you come by his purse?"
means: How did you get his purse?

Come by – पाना, प्राप्त करना (विशेष रूप से जब तरीका स्पष्ट न हो)

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Come off – Means to succeed or happen as planned (सफल होना या उतर जाना), unrelated

  • Come into – Usually refers to inheritance or possession (जैसे संपत्ति मिलना), but not suitable here

  • Come out – Means to appear or become visible/published (प्रकट होना), unrelated

Therefore, the correct phrasal verb is “come by.”

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.
I have been wondering a̲t̲ ̲t̲a̲k̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲skating as a hobby.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 12 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

❌ What's wrong?

  • The phrase “wondering at taking” is incorrect both grammatically and idiomatically.

  • The correct phrasal structure is:

  • “wondering about doing something” (thinking or considering doing something)

Also, in this context:

  • We usually say: “take up” a hobby
    (meaning: to start a new hobby or activity)

✅ Correct structure:

“I have been wondering about taking up skating as a hobby.”

  • “about” → correct preposition with “wondering”

  • “taking up” → correct phrasal verb for beginning a hobby

❌ Why other options are incorrect:

  • on taking to – unidiomatic in this context

  • to take up – incorrect with “wondering”; “wondering to” is not used

  • No improvement required – the original sentence is ungrammatical

✅ Therefore, the correct improvement is: about taking up.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
A few boys were k̲e̲p̲t̲ ̲u̲p̲ because of disobedience.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-1 (9_00 to 11_00 AM))
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is: kept back

Kept back: This phrase means to hold something or someone back, which can be used in the context of holding someone in reserve or not allowing them to advance. In the context of the sentence, "A few boys were kept back because of disobedience" suggests that these boys were not allowed to move forward or progress, possibly due to disciplinary reasons. This is the most suitable option.

Kept on: This phrase typically means to continue doing something. For example, "He kept on working despite the challenges." It doesn't fit the context of the sentence, which suggests a consequence for disobedience.

Kept off: This phrase usually means to stay away or refrain from something. For example, "He kept off the grass." It doesn't convey the idea of consequence for disobedience as needed in the sentence.

Kept in: This phrase generally means to stay indoors or remain inside a particular place. For example, "I kept in during the rain." It doesn't convey the idea of a consequence for disobedience.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.
My father was always o̲r̲d̲e̲r̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲a̲b̲o̲u̲t̲ ̲m̲y̲ ̲s̲i̲s̲t̲e̲r̲.̲

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 13 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
option_3: giving order for my sister
solution:
Explanation:

⚠️ What’s the issue?

  • The phrase “ordering about my sister” is incorrect word order in English.

  • The correct and idiomatic expression is:
    ✅ “ordering my sister about”, which means repeatedly giving commands to her in a bossy or dominating way.

✅ Correct Usage:

  • “order someone about” = to boss someone around
    (किसी को बार-बार आदेश देना / हुक्म चलाना)

✅ Correct sentence:

My father was always ordering my sister about.

❌ Why other options are incorrect:

  • ordering on my sister – ❌ Not a valid phrasal verb

  • giving order for my sister – ❌ Unnatural and incorrect structure

  • No improvement required – ❌ Because original has incorrect word order

✔️ Final Answer: ordering my sister about ✅

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution required’.
H̲e̲a̲r̲s̲ ̲t̲o̲ the news tonight at 9 p.m., as there will be an important announcement about the budget.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 17 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Correct Answer: Listen to

Solution:
The correct phrase is "Listen to the news", not "Hears to the news".
"Listen to" is the proper verb phrase used when advising someone to pay attention to sound actively (like a broadcast).
Option (2) Hear to is grammatically incorrect — we say “hear something” but not “hear to”.
Option (3) No substitution required is incorrect because the original phrase is wrong.
Option (4) Listened to is past tense, but the sentence is in imperative/future context.

Correct sentence:
"Listen to the news tonight at 9 p.m., as there will be an important announcement about the budget."

Difficult Words and Meanings:
listen to – to pay attention to sound – ध्यान से सुनना
announcement – an official statement or declaration – घोषणा
budget – a financial plan – बजट / अनुमानित व्यय

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
They have d̲i̲s̲p̲o̲s̲e̲d̲ all the old books.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 17 July Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: disposed of
Solution:

  • The correct phrasal verb is "dispose of", which means to get rid of something (किसी चीज़ को हटाना या फेंकना).

  • Correct sentence: They have disposed of all the old books.

  • Let's review the other options:

  • disposed on – incorrect preposition

  • disposed by – grammatically incorrect in this context

  • disposed out – not a valid phrasal verb

  • Therefore, the correct substitution is: disposed of.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Unless we c̲o̲-̲o̲p̲e̲r̲a̲t̲e̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲w̲o̲r̲k̲ ̲t̲o̲g̲e̲t̲h̲e̲r̲, we cannot succeed.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-1)
solution:
Answer: ✅ pull together

Explanation:

  • The original sentence is:

Unless we cooperate and work together, we cannot succeed.

We are looking for a phrasal verb that means the same as “cooperate and work together.”

Let’s look at the meanings of the options:

  • pull down – to demolish or reduce (e.g., a building) ❌

  • pull through – to recover from illness or a difficult situation ❌

  • pull together – to cooperate and work in unity ✅

  • pull up – to stop or lift something ❌

✅ Therefore, the correct substitution is: pull together

Rewritten sentence:

*Unless we pull together, we cannot

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
One must b̲r̲u̲s̲h̲ ̲u̲p̲ ̲o̲n̲ entire course before the day of examination.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-1)
solution:
Answer:(a) No substitution

Explanation:

  • The phrasal verb “brush up on” means to quickly review or refresh one’s knowledge of something (किसी विषय को दोबारा पढ़कर याद करना), especially before an exam.

  • The sentence is correct: “One must brush up on [the] entire course…”

Other options:

  • brushing on / brushing off / brush about – ❌ incorrect or irrelevant usages

✅ So, no substitution is required — the original sentence is correct.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
The staff member c̲o̲u̲l̲d̲ ̲n̲o̲t̲ ̲s̲h̲o̲w̲ ̲o̲f̲f̲ that day to the office as his ward was ill.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-3)
solution:
Answer: (d) could not show up

Explanation:

  • The phrase “show off” means to brag or display something proudly, which does not fit the context of attending or appearing at the office.

  • The correct phrase is “show up”, meaning to appear or attend (पहुंचना).

  • Since the sentence is in the past tense (“could not”), “could not show up” is the appropriate substitution.

  • Other options either have incorrect tense or wrong phrase.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed select ‘No improvement required’.
He f̲e̲l̲l̲ ̲o̲v̲e̲r̲ in studies owing to his illness.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 18 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
solution:
Answer: fell behind

Solution:

  • “Fell behind” means to fail to keep up with progress, especially in studies.

  • His illness caused him to miss classes and assignments, so he fell behind in his studies.

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • fell over – means to physically trip or tumble, not to lag academically.

  • fell out – means to have a dispute or for something to drop out, not to fall behind in work.

  • fell for – means to be deceived or to fall in love, unrelated to studies.

  • No improvement required – suggests the original phrase is correct, but “fell over in studies” is nonidiomatic and doesn’t convey the intended meaning.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
Please ask the dog to g̲e̲t̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲m̲y̲ couch.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 18 July Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: get off my
Solution:

  • The underlined phrase is: “get of my couch” – which is incorrect because the correct phrasal verb is “get off”, not “get of”.

  • The correct sentence should be: “Please ask the dog to get off my couch.”

  • Option analysis:

  • get off mine – grammatically correct but changes the meaning (mine = possession, not the actual couch)

  • ✅ get off my – correct phrasing (get off my couch)

  • No substitution – incorrect, because the original phrase is wrong

  • get of mine – incorrect preposition

  • ✅ Therefore, the correct substitution is: get off my.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
Some children surprisingly t̲a̲k̲e̲ ̲o̲n̲ their grandparents in appearance.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
solution:
Answer: (d) take after
Explanation: The phrasal verb “take on” means to accept a challenge or responsibility (जिम्मेदारी लेना), which does not fit the context here. The sentence talks about children resembling their grandparents in appearance.
 The correct phrasal verb is “take after”, which means to resemble a family member in appearance or behaviour (दिखने या व्यवहार में किसी परिवार के सदस्य जैसा होना).
 So, the correct sentence is: “Some children surprisingly take after their grandparents in appearance.”
 Other options:
 (a) taking after – incorrect tense ❌
 (b) take later – meaningless in context ❌
 (c) No substitution – incorrect, as a substitution is needed ❌
 ✅ Hence, the correct answer is: (d) take after.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
It was getting difficult for him t̲o̲ ̲b̲e̲a̲r̲ ̲w̲i̲t̲h̲ his partner’s behaviour.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
solution:
Correct Answer: No substitution
Explanation:
 The phrase "to bear with" means to tolerate or endure (सहना / बर्दाश्त करना).
 In the sentence, "It was getting difficult for him to bear with his partner’s behaviour", the usage is correct and conveys that he was finding it hard to tolerate the behaviour.
 Let’s look at the meanings of other options:
To bank on – to rely on (भरोसा करना)
To bear out – to confirm something (सत्यापित करना)
To bail out – to rescue someone from a difficult situation, often involving money (किसी की सहायता करना/जमानत देना)
 None of these are suitable substitutes for "to bear with" in this context.
 Hence, No substitution is needed.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
Having t̲u̲r̲n̲e̲d̲ ̲u̲p̲ on the proposal, I felt disappointed over the entire issue.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
solution:
Correct Answer: turned down
Explanation:
 The phrase "turned up" means to arrive or appear (पहुंचना), which does not fit the context of the sentence.
 The correct phrasal verb here should be "turned down", which means to reject or refuse (अस्वीकार करना).

Correct sentence: Having turned down the proposal, I felt disappointed over the entire issue.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
It is quite difficult to m̲a̲k̲e̲ ̲o̲n̲ what this doctor writes.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 20 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Phrasal Verb:

✅ Make out
→ means to decipher, understand, or read with difficulty
(समझना / पढ़ पाना, ख़ासकर जब कुछ अस्पष्ट या कठिन लिखा हो)

🔹 Sentence Meaning:

“It is quite difficult to understand/read what this doctor writes.”
👉 This clearly requires "make out"

🔍 Option-wise Evaluation:

🔸 Option A: made on

  • ❌ Incorrect

  • "made" is past tense and doesn’t fit the infinitive “to ___” structure

  • "made on" is not a valid phrasal verb

🔸 Option B: make in

  • ❌ Incorrect

  • “make in” is not a valid phrasal verb in this context

  • Doesn’t convey the idea of understanding/deciphering

🔸 Option C: No substitution required

  • ❌ Incorrect

  • “make on” is grammatically and semantically incorrect

🔸 Option D: make out

  • ✅ Correct

  • Proper phrasal verb for “understand or read with difficulty”

  • Correct verb form after “to” (to make out)

✅ Final Answer: D. make out

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
Delegates of the conflicting countries formally meet at a conference t̲o̲ ̲i̲r̲o̲n̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲ their differences.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 24 July Shift-3)
solution:
Answer:(1) to iron out

Solution:
The correct phrase is “to iron out”, which means to resolve or settle differences (समस्याओं को सुलझाना).

Correct sentence:
“Delegates of the conflicting countries formally meet at a conference to iron out their differences.”

Other options:

  • No substitution – Incorrect as the original phrase may be incorrectly spaced or formatted.

  • to ironed – Incorrect verb form.

  • for iron in – Incorrect phrase.

Word Meanings:

  • Iron out – सुलझाना / निपटाना

  • Delegate – प्रतिनिधि

  • Conflicting – विवादित

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The commanders e̲n̲t̲e̲r̲e̲d̲ ̲b̲y̲ ̲f̲o̲r̲c̲e̲ ̲i̲n̲t̲o̲ terrorists’ camp.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 25 July Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: broke into
Solution:

  • The phrase “entered by force” means to forcefully go inside a place, which is best expressed by the phrasal verb “broke into”.

  • "Break into" means to enter a place forcibly, especially to commit an act like an arrest or attack (बलपूर्वक घुसना). ✅

  • Option meanings:

  • Broke with – to end a relationship or association (संबंध तोड़ना) ❌

  • Broke off – to stop suddenly or discontinue (अचानक रोकना) ❌

  • Broke down – to stop working or collapse emotionally (बिगड़ जाना / टूट जाना) ❌

  • Broke into – to enter by force (बलपूर्वक प्रवेश करना) ✅

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
He was a̲d̲v̲i̲s̲e̲d̲ ̲f̲o̲r̲ walking alone in the neighbourhood.

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 27 June Shift-4 )
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment "advised for" in the given sentence is: advised against

"Advised against" means to receive counsel or recommendation not to do something. In the context of the sentence, if someone is advised against walking alone in the neighborhood, it implies that they are being cautioned or warned not to do so due to potential dangers or risks.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The rebels l̲a̲i̲d̲ ̲u̲p̲ their arms.

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 27 June Shift-4 )
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is: laid down

laid down: This phrase means to surrender, relinquish, or deposit something, often used in the context of giving up weapons or authority. For example, "The soldiers laid down their weapons."

laid on: This phrase typically means to arrange or provide something, often in terms of organizing an event or activity. For example, "The host laid on a fantastic spread for the party."

laid out: This phrase has multiple meanings, but in this context, it means to arrange or display something, often in a deliberate or organized manner. For example, "She laid out the ingredients neatly on the counter before starting to cook."

laid by: This phrase typically means to set aside or save something for future use, particularly in terms of money or resources. For example, "He laid by a portion of his earnings each month for his retirement fund."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
This case is serious. You need to l̲o̲o̲k̲ ̲i̲n̲t̲o̲ this matter; otherwise, the situation will get out of control soon.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 3 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is: look into

Look up: Typically means to search for information in a reference source, like a book or online.

Look after: Means to take care of or be responsible for someone or something.

Look at: Refers to directing your gaze towards something, observing, or examining visually.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
The patient was suggested to c̲u̲t̲ ̲o̲f̲f̲ on the daily intake of carbs.

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 30 June Shift-1 )
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment "cut off" in the given sentence is: cut down

"Cut off" is not the most suitable option here because it doesn't convey the intended meaning accurately. "Cut down" is the correct phrasal verb to use in this context, meaning to reduce or decrease something, such as the intake of carbs.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Athira would like to get him a special birthday present, but nothing s̲p̲r̲i̲n̲g̲s̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲m̲i̲n̲d̲.

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 30 June Shift-4)
option_3: from the beginning of time
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment "springs to mind" in the given sentence is: dawns on

Dawns on: This phrase means to suddenly become understood or realized by someone. In the context of the sentence, it accurately conveys Athira's experience of suddenly realizing or understanding that she can't think of a suitable birthday present.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
A gust of wind came abruptly and our sand castle t̲o̲p̲p̲l̲e̲d̲.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment "toppled" in the given sentence is: tumbled down
tumbled down: This phrase means to fall suddenly and rapidly, often in a disorganized manner. In the context of the sentence, it implies that the sand castle collapsed or fell apart.
Blew out: This phrase typically refers to extinguishing something by blowing air on it. For example, blowing out candles on a birthday cake. In the context of the sentence, it doesn't accurately convey the idea of the sand castle collapsing due to wind.
Turned up: This phrase can have multiple meanings depending on the context. It can mean to increase in volume or intensity, to arrive or appear unexpectedly, or to overturn something. In the context of the sentence, it doesn't convey the idea of the sand castle collapsing.
Ran after: This phrase means to chase or pursue someone or something. In the context of the sentence, it doesn't fit as it doesn't convey the idea of the sand castle collapsing due to wind.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The lease of our house has r̲u̲n̲ ̲d̲o̲w̲n̲.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: 3 (run out)

Solution (Correct Option - 3: run out):
The sentence is:
"The lease of our house has run down."

This is incorrect, as “run down” typically means to decline in condition (e.g., a battery or a person).
When referring to something expiring or reaching its end (like a lease, contract, or subscription), the correct phrasal verb is “run out.”

✔ Correct sentence:
"The lease of our house has run out."
→ (The lease has expired.)

Why other options are incorrect:
Run apart – not a standard phrasal verb.
Run into – means to meet or encounter, especially unexpectedly (भेंट हो जाना); unrelated here.
Run up to – means to approach a time or event (e.g., in the run-up to elections); not suitable for lease expiry.

Difficult Word Meanings:
Run out – to expire or be used up (समाप्त हो जाना)
Lease – a legal agreement for rental (पट्टा, किरायानामा)

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
They a̲r̲e̲ ̲l̲o̲o̲k̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲t̲o̲ a place to rest.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 1 (are looking for)

Solution:
The sentence is:
"They are looking to a place to rest." – This is incorrect, because the phrase “looking to” doesn’t fit the meaning of searching for something.

The correct phrasal verb is “looking for”, which means searching for.

✔ Correct sentence:
"They are looking for a place to rest."

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Have looking at – grammatically incorrect; "have" doesn't go with "looking" like this.

  • Looking into – means to investigate, not search for a location.

  • Should be looking – changes the tense and meaning unnecessarily.

Phrase Meaning:
Looking for – trying to find something (कुछ ढूंढ़ रहे हैं)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
You must c̲u̲t̲ ̲o̲f̲f̲ your expenses if you want to save money.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 3 (cut down on)

Solution:
The sentence is:
"You must cut off your expenses if you want to save money."

The phrase “cut off” is incorrect in this context. "Cut off" means to disconnect or remove entirely (जैसे बिजली काटना), which doesn't fit naturally with expenses.

The correct phrasal verb is “cut down on”, which means to reduce the amount or quantity of something, especially spending or consumption.

✔ Correct sentence:
"You must cut down on your expenses if you want to save money."

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Cut up – means to chop into pieces (काटना), irrelevant here.

  • Cut out – can mean to eliminate, but it's not commonly used with "expenses" in this context.

  • Cut for – not a valid phrase in this sense.

Difficult Word Meaning:
Cut down on – to reduce (कमी करना)
Expenses – खर्चे (spending)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The doctors have g̲i̲v̲e̲n̲ ̲o̲f̲f̲ the case.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 1 (given up)

Solution:
The sentence is:
"The doctors have given off the case."

The phrasal verb “given off” is incorrect here.

  • “Give off” means to emit (like smell, light, or heat), which doesn’t fit this context.

The correct phrase is “given up”, which means to stop trying or to quit, especially when someone abandons an effort or responsibility — like dropping a case.

✔ Correct sentence:
"The doctors have given up the case."

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Given over – means to hand over or surrender control, not natural here.

  • Given out – means to distribute or emit, not about abandoning something.

  • Given forth – archaic and rarely used; not correct here.

Difficult Word Meanings:
Give up – to quit or abandon (छोड़ देना)
Give off – to emit (निकालना, जैसे धुआँ या गंध)
Give out – to distribute or emit (बांटना या समाप्त हो जाना)
Give over – to hand something to someone (सौंप देना)

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined word segment in the given sentence.
Her thinning grey hair was h̲a̲n̲g̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲o̲n̲ her bony forehead.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 18-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct Answer: straggling over

Explanation:
The correct phrase is "straggling over", which means hanging loosely and untidily over something. This best describes the appearance of thinning grey hair over a bony forehead.

Other Options:

  • sinking from – Incorrect; "sinking" means moving downward,

  • urging ahead – Incorrect; "urging ahead" means pushing forward with determination,

  • falling about – Incorrect; "falling about" usually refers to uncontrolled movement, such as laughing or stumbling,

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
During the preparation for competitive exams, Meena a̲v̲o̲i̲d̲e̲d̲ going to parties.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-2)
solution:
The correct answer is:

B) steered clear of

Explanation:

"Steered clear of" is an idiom that means to deliberately avoid something, which fits the context of Meena avoiding going to parties.

The other options do not fit the meaning:

  • Whispered a secret: Means to share a secret quietly.

  • Fired a cracker: Refers to setting off fireworks.

  • Cracked a joke: Means to make a humorous remark.
